</div><div class="html-p">In conclusion, quantum computing represents one of the most transformative trends in the evolving landscape of parallel systems. By harnessing the fundamental principles of quantum mechanics, quantum computing is poised to complement classical HPC, unlocking unprecedented computational power for scientific discovery and industrial applications.</div></section><section id="sec3dot3-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h4 class="html-italic" data-nested="2" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  3.3. Neuromorphic Computing</h4><div class="html-p">Neuromorphic computing is a class of brain-inspired computing architectures which, at a certain level of abstraction, simulate the biological computations of the brain. This approach enhances the efficiency of compatible computational tasks and achieves computational delays and energy consumption with biological computation. The term “neuromorphic” was introduced by Carver Mead in the late 1980s [<a href="#B53-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">53</a>,<a href="#B54-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">54</a>], referring to mixed analogue–digital implementations of brain-inspired computing. Over time, as technology evolved, it came to encompass a wider range of brain-inspired hardware implementations. Specifically, unlike the von Neumann architecture’s CPU–memory separation and synchronous clocking, neuromorphic computing utilises neurons and synapses, the fundamental components, to integrate computation and memory. It employs an event-driven approach based on asynchronous event-based spikes, which is more efficient for the brain-like sparse and massively parallel computing, significantly reducing energy consumption. At the algorithmic level, the brain-inspired Spike Neural Network (SNN) serves as an essential algorithm deployed on neuromorphic hardware, efficiently completing ML tasks [<a href="#B55-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">55</a>,<a href="#B56-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">56</a>] and other operations [<a href="#B57-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">57</a>,<a href="#B58-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">58</a>]. Recent advancements in VLSI technology and AI have propelled neuromorphic computing towards large-scale development [<a href="#B59-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">59</a>]. This introduces developments in neuromorphic computing from both hardware and algorithmic perspectives and discusses future trends.</div><div class="html-p">IBM TrueNorth is based on distributed digital neural models designed to address cognitive tasks in real time [<a href="#B60-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">60</a>]. Its chip contains 4096 neurosynaptic cores, each core featuring 256 neurons, with each neuron having 256 synaptic connections. On the one hand, the intra-chip network integrates 1 million programmable neurons and 256 million trainable synapses; on the other hand, the inter-chip interface supports seamless multi-chip communication of arbitrary size, facilitating parallel computation. By using offline learning, various common algorithms such as convolutional networks, restricted Boltzmann machines, hidden Markov models, and multi-modal classification have been mapped to TrueNorth, achieving good results in real-time multi-object detection and classification tasks with milliwatt-level energy consumption.</div><div class="html-p">Neurogrid, a tree-structured neuromorphic computing architecture, fully considers neural features such as the axonal arbor, synapse, dendritic tree, and ion channels to maximise synaptic connections [<a href="#B61-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">61</a>]. Neurogrid uses analogue signals to save energy and a tree structure to maximise throughput, allowing it to simulate 1 million neurons and billions of synaptic connections with only 16 neurocores and a power consumption of only 3 watts. Neurogrid’s hardware is suitable for real-time simulation, while its software can be used for interactive visualisation.</div><div class="html-p">As one of the neuromorphic computing platforms contributing to the European Union Flagship Human Brain Project (HBP), SpiNNaker is a parallel computation architecture with a million cores [<a href="#B62-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">62</a>]. Each SpiNNaker node has 18 cores, connected by a system network-on-chip. Nodes select 1 neural core to act as the monitor processor, assigned an operating system support role, while the other 16 cores support application roles, with the 18th core reserved as a fault-tolerance spare. Nodes communicate through a router to complete parallel data exchange. SpiNNaker can be used as an interface with AER sensors and for integration with robotic platforms.</div><div class="html-p">Intel’s Loihi is a neuromorphic research processor supporting multi-scale SNNs, achieving performance comparable to mainstream computing architectures [<a href="#B63-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">63</a>,<a href="#B64-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">64</a>]. Loihi features a maximum of 128,000 neurons per chip with 128 million synapses. Its unique capabilities include a highly configurable synaptic memory with variable weight precision, support for a wide range of plasticity rules, and graded reward spikes that facilitate learning. Loihi has been evaluated in various applications, such as adaptive robot arm control, visual–tactile sensory perception, modelling diffusion processes for scientific computing applications, and solving hard optimisation problems like railway scheduling. Loihi2 [<a href="#B65-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">65</a>], as a new generation of neuromorphic computing and an upgrade of Loihi, is equipped with generalised event-based messaging, greater neuron model programmability, enhanced learning capabilities, numerous capacity optimisations to improve resource density, and faster circuit speeds. Importantly, besides the features from Loihi1, Loihi2 has shared synapses for convolution, which is ideal for deep convolutional neural networks.</div><div class="html-p">SNNs are an essential algorithmic component of neuromorphic computing. To accomplish a task, we should consider how to define a tailored SNN and deploy it on hardware [<a href="#B54-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">54</a>]. From a training perspective, algorithms can be categorised into online learning and offline learning. The offline-learning approach first deploys the SNN on neuromorphic hardware and then uses the plasticity features to approximate backpropagation. This is a real-time method for optimising hardware simulation of plasticity. Offline learning involves training an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) on a CPU or GPU based on specific tasks and data, then converting the ANN to an equivalent SNN and deploying it on neuromorphic hardware. As a key to training algorithms, various studies have analysed backpropagation.</div><div class="html-p">An Energy-Efficient Backpropagation approach successfully implemented backpropagation on TrueNorth hardware [<a href="#B56-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">56</a>]. Importantly, this method treats spikes and discrete synapses as continuous probabilities, allowing the trained network to map to neuromorphic hardware through probability sampling. This training method achieved 99.42% accuracy on the MNIST dataset with only 0.268 mJ per image. Furthermore, backpropagation through time (BPTT) has been implemented on neuromorphic datasets, providing a training method for recurrent structures on neuromorphic platforms [<a href="#B66-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">66</a>]. Benefiting from these training optimisations, SNNs in neuromorphic computing have been applied in various ML tasks such as Simultaneous Velocity and Texture Classification [<a href="#B67-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">67</a>], Real-time Facial Expression Recognition [<a href="#B68-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">68</a>], and EMG Gesture Classification [<a href="#B69-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">69</a>]. Similarly, they have been used in neuroscience research [<a href="#B70-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">70</a>,<a href="#B71-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">71</a>]. SNN-based neuromorphic computing is also utilised in non-ML tasks. Benefiting from the neuromorphic vertex–edge structure, graph theory problems can be mapped onto the hardware [<a href="#B58-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">58</a>,<a href="#B72-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">72</a>,<a href="#B73-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">73</a>]. Additionally, it has been applied to solving NP-complete problems [<a href="#B74-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">74</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Neuromorphic computing often aims to replicate aspects of biological neural processing in hardware, but there is an ongoing debate over how strictly such systems must adhere to biophysical plausibility versus employing more abstract ML methods. On the one hand, SNN models, such as the Izhikevich formulation [<a href="#B75-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">75</a>], focus on capturing the temporal dynamics of real neurons, which can yield insights into how biological brains encode and process information. Research has shown that such models can replicate a variety of neuronal firing patterns with computational efficiency, providing a bridge between computational neuroscience and neuromorphic engineering [<a href="#B76-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">76</a>]. On the other hand, more traditional ML algorithms, such as Bayesian inference [<a href="#B77-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">77</a>], support vector machines [<a href="#B78-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">78</a>], or the large language models [<a href="#B79-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">79</a>] dominating modern AI, tend to trade some fidelity to biological detail for mathematical tractability, scalability, and often better empirical performance on a range of industrial tasks.</div><div class="html-p">Despite the proven feasibility of neuromorphic computing in many tasks, it remains largely experimental. In today’s landscape of energy-consuming AI driven by GPU clusters, bringing neuromorphic computing out of the lab and achieving performance equal to or better than GPU-based AI with low energy consumption is a significant trend [<a href="#B80-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">80</a>,<a href="#B81-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">81</a>,<a href="#B82-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">82</a>]. Standardised hardware protocols and community-maintained software will be crucial. From a neuroscience research perspective, neuromorphic computing simulates brain structures to varying degrees. Leveraging these simulations could provide new insights into neural mechanisms and brain function. Neuromorphic computing has a close-loop relationship with both AI and neuroscience, drawing inspiration from and serving both fields, tightly linking their development and advancing our understanding of intelligence.</div></section><section id="sec3dot4-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h4 class="html-italic" data-nested="2" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  3.4. Optical Computing</h4><div class="html-p">Optical computing utilises the properties of light to perform parallel computations, providing the potential to significantly exceed the speed and efficiency of electronic computing [<a href="#B83-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">83</a>]. Unlike electronic computing, which relies on the movement of electrical charges, optical computing uses photons to carry and process information. Because light travels faster and experiences minimal resistance, optical computing has the potential to significantly improve processing speeds and energy efficiency. Research in optical computing can be traced back to the early 1960s [<a href="#B84-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">84</a>]. Over the years, the primary focus of optical computing has been on integrating optical components for communication within computer systems or incorporating optical functions due to advances in electronic technology [<a href="#B84-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">84</a>]. Although these elements remain under development and have yet to mature, the adaptation and exploration of optical computing, especially in AI, have grown rapidly in recent years due to the boom in AI and the limitations of traditional electrical architectures. To explore the emerging trends in optical computing, we first examine the different categories of optical computing systems and then discuss the potential and outlook of optical computing in AI.</div><div class="html-p">Optical computing systems can be categorised into analogue, digital, and hybrid optical computing systems (OCS). Each category differs in how it processes information, balancing speed, precision, and scalability. Analogue optical computing systems (AOCS) utilise the continuous nature of light to perform computations, leveraging properties such as intensity, phase, and wavelength to represent and process data. This enables high precision and real-time processing capabilities, making AOCS suitable for signal processing and image recognition applications. On the other hand, digital optical computing systems (DOCS) operate on binary principles similar to traditional electronic computers, where light is used to represent binary data (0’s and 1’s) and perform logical operations through optical gates. DOCS can achieve exceptionally high-speed processing and parallelism, ideal for tasks requiring rapid data computation. However, scalability and integration difficulties pose significant challenges for DOCS, particularly in large-scale systems. Hybrid optical computing systems (HOCS) combine the strengths of both analogue and digital approaches, integrating continuous and discrete data representations to optimise performance across a broader range of applications. By leveraging the unique advantages of light, such as its speed and bandwidth, these hybrid systems can enhance computational efficiency and open new frontiers in fields such as telecommunications, AI, and scientific simulations. <a href="#table_body_display_electronics-14-00677-t001" class="html-table html-tablepopup">Table 1</a> summarises the features of these three systems.</div><div class="html-table-wrap" id="electronics-14-00677-t001"><div class="html-table_wrap_discription">
    <b>Table 1.</b>
    Comparison of optical computing systems. This table compares analogue optical computing systems (AOCS), digital optical computing systems (DOCS), and hybrid optical computing systems (HOCS) based on key characteristics such as data type, speed, error susceptibility, complexity, integration challenges, and applications.
  </div>
  <div class="html-table_wrap_td">
    <div class="html-tablepopup html-tablepopup-link" data-counterslinkmanual="https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9292/14/4/677/display" href="#table_body_display_electronics-14-00677-t001">
        <img data-lsrc="https://pub.mdpi-res.com/img/table.png" src="https://pub.mdpi-res.com/img/table.png">
       <a class="html-expand html-tablepopup" data-counterslinkmanual="https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9292/14/4/677/display" href="#table_body_display_electronics-14-00677-t001"></a>
    </div>

  </div>
  
</div><div class="html-p">Optical computing also leverages optical components such as microring resonators (MRRs) and Mach–Zehnder interferometers (MZIs) to design essential elements such as logic gates, switches, storage devices, routers, and photonic integrated circuits. Microring resonators act as miniature loops that guide and filter light, while Mach–Zehnder interferometers function as optical switches, enabling precise control over light-based computations. The development of these components has been pivotal in advancing the field, leading to the creation of more compact and powerful photonic circuits. Initially, research focused on the fundamental properties of light and how it could be manipulated for computation. Over time, advancements in materials science and nanofabrication have enabled greater miniaturisation and improved integration of optical components.</div><div class="html-p">Optical computing is making significant strides across multiple domains, particularly in telecommunications, AI, and HPC. Key areas of impact include the following: <span class="html-italic">1. Telecommunications:</span> Optical components enhance data transmission speeds and network capacity. Photonic technologies in fibre-optic networks reduce latency and increase bandwidth, making them integral to modern communication infrastructures [<a href="#B85-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">85</a>]. <span class="html-italic">2. AI:</span> Optical neural networks, particularly those utilising MZIs, enable AI computations at speeds beyond conventional electronic processors. One notable example is the use of optical matrix multiplication for accelerating deep learning models, significantly reducing energy consumption in AI training [<a href="#B86-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">86</a>]. <span class="html-italic">3. HPC:</span> The integration of photonic integrated circuits (PICs) and photonic–electronic co-design is advancing HPC infrastructures [<a href="#B87-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">87</a>]. The adoption of optical interconnects in HPC provides high bandwidth and lower energy consumption, significantly improving data transfer efficiency for large-scale simulations and AI training [<a href="#B88-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">88</a>]. Despite these advancements, optical computing still faces challenges, including manufacturing complexities, optical loss, and crosstalk, which hinder large-scale adoption [<a href="#B89-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">89</a>]. However, ongoing research in photonic materials and integrated circuit design continues to address these limitations, paving the way for more scalable optical computing solutions.</div><div class="html-p">Optical computing has evolved significantly with advances in component technology, growing applications, and increasing research interest. While it is not yet poised to replace electronic computing entirely, it is expected to play a complementary role, particularly in areas demanding ultra-fast, energy-efficient computations. As research progresses, breakthroughs in nanophotonics, integrated optical chips, and AI-driven photonic computing will likely drive optical computing toward mainstream adoption. With further improvements in scalability and integration, optical computing may soon redefine HPC, revolutionising fields such as AI, communications, and beyond. For readers interested in a more in-depth exploration of optical computing, the review papers [<a href="#B84-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">84</a>,<a href="#B86-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">86</a>,<a href="#B90-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">90</a>], as well as the book [<a href="#B91-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">91</a>], provide comprehensive insights into its fundamentals and applications.</div></section></section><section id="sec4-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h2 data-nested="1" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  4. Emerging Trends in Distributed Systems</h2><div class="html-p">In the rapidly evolving landscape of computing, distributed systems have become integral to handling the scale, complexity, and diversity of modern applications. By leveraging multiple interconnected computing resources, distributed systems provide scalable, resilient, and efficient solutions that traditional centralised systems cannot offer. As data volumes grow exponentially and applications demand real-time processing and decision-making, innovative approaches in distributed computing are essential. This section explores the emerging trends in distributed systems, focusing on four key areas: blockchain and distributed ledgers, serverless computing, cloud-native architectures, and distributed AI and ML systems. These advancements are redefining how data are managed, processed, and secured across various industries, enabling new possibilities while addressing critical scalability, efficiency, security, and privacy challenges.</div><section id="sec4dot1-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h4 class="html-italic" data-nested="2" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  4.1. Blockchain and Distributed Ledgers</h4><div class="html-p">The concept of the blockchain was first coined by Satoshi Nakamoto in 2008 after the failure of the global financial system in 2007 [<a href="#B92-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">92</a>]. Though he did not formally define the blockchain, he demonstrated the blockchain concept for electronic cash (called Bitcoin) transfers where no central authority is needed to prevent double-spending. The first successful Bitcoin transaction took place in 2009 when Satoshi Nakamoto transferred 10 BTC (Bitcoin) to Hal Finney. Satoshi uses a peer-to-peer network to timestamp transactions through a hash-based Proof-of-Work chain, which acts as an unchangeable record unless the Proof of Work is redone. However, the concept of blockchain is fundamentally based on three elements: (i) blind signature, a cryptographic concept proposed by David Chaum in 1989 for automation of payment [<a href="#B93-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">93</a>]; (ii) timestamped documents which secure digital documents by stamping the documents with the date [<a href="#B94-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">94</a>]; and (iii) Reusable Proof of Work (RPoW), a mechanism for preventing double-spending and securing decentralized networks, later extended into a reusable format by Hal Finney in 2004 [<a href="#B95-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">95</a>]. Therefore, researchers formally defined the blockchain as a meta-technology which combines several computing techniques [<a href="#B96-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">96</a>]. However, the most widely adopted definition of blockchain is a distributed digital ledger technology with a ledger of transactions, or blocks, that form a systematic, linear chain of all transactions ever made. Blockchain presents timestamped and immutable blocks of highly encrypted and anonymised data not owned or mediated by any specific person or groups [<a href="#B97-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">97</a>,<a href="#B98-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">98</a>]. A block in a blockchain is primarily identified by its block header hash or block hash, a cryptographic hash made by hashing the block header twice through the SHA256 algorithm. In addition, a block can also be identified by the block height, which is its position in the blockchain or the number of blocks preceding it in the blockchain. The Merkle tree offers a secure and efficient way to create a digital fingerprint for the complete set of transactions. A blockchain structure is shown in <a href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f006" class="html-fig html-figpopup">Figure 6</a>, where blocks are connected through their respective hash code.</div><div class="html-fig-wrap" id="electronics-14-00677-f006">
  <div class="html-fig_img">
    <div class="html-figpopup html-figpopup-link" data-counterslinkmanual="https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9292/14/4/677/display" href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f006">
      <img data-large="/electronics/electronics-14-00677/article_deploy/html/images/electronics-14-00677-g006.png" data-original="/electronics/electronics-14-00677/article_deploy/html/images/electronics-14-00677-g006.png" alt="Electronics 14 00677 g006" data-lsrc="/electronics/electronics-14-00677/article_deploy/html/images/electronics-14-00677-g006-550.jpg" src="/electronics/electronics-14-00677/article_deploy/html/images/electronics-14-00677-g006-550.jpg">
      <a class="html-expand html-figpopup" data-counterslinkmanual="https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9292/14/4/677/display" href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f006"></a>

      Click here to enlarge figure
    </a></p> -->

  </div>
</div><div class="html-p">Distributed ledger technology (DLT) is the underlying generalised concept that makes the blockchain work in a distributed platform. The concept of DLT incorporates principles from “The Byzantine General Problem”, described by Lamport et al. [<a href="#B99-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">99</a>], which evaluates the strategies for achieving consensus in distributed systems despite conflicting information in an adversarial environment. Consensus protocols, like Proof of Stake, allow participants to achieve a shared view of the ledger without intermediaries. Emerging mechanisms, such as Proof of Space and Proof of Authority [<a href="#B100-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">100</a>], have gained attention for their lower energy consumption and faster transaction verification times compared to Proof of Work. These mechanisms aim to address the inefficiencies and environmental impacts associated with traditional methods, offering tailored solutions for specific use cases. Additionally, cryptographic techniques, such as the Schnorr Signature Scheme and Merkle Tree, enhance data integrity and trust within blockchain frameworks, reinforcing secure data verification processes [<a href="#B101-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">101</a>]. A distributed ledger is a digital record maintained across a network of machines, known as nodes, with any updates being reflected simultaneously for all participants and authenticated through cryptographic signatures [<a href="#B102-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">102</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Beyond cryptocurrencies, blockchain’s applications span a wide range of industries, including eHealth [<a href="#B103-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">103</a>,<a href="#B104-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">104</a>], intellectual property [<a href="#B105-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">105</a>,<a href="#B106-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">106</a>], education, digital identity, finance [<a href="#B107-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">107</a>,<a href="#B108-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">108</a>,<a href="#B109-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">109</a>], supply chain [<a href="#B110-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">110</a>,<a href="#B111-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">111</a>,<a href="#B112-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">112</a>], IoT [<a href="#B113-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">113</a>,<a href="#B114-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">114</a>,<a href="#B115-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">115</a>], etc. In supply chain management, blockchain frameworks such as IBM Food Trust provide end-to-end traceability, ensuring transparency and accountability. Case studies, such as Walmart’s use of blockchain to track food provenance, have quantified significant reductions in tracing times, from days to seconds, illustrating blockchain’s potential to streamline operations and mitigate fraud. In healthcare, blockchain’s anonymity and immutability features make it unparalleled for secure information sharing among different providers, forming the foundation of modern healthcare, alternatively termed Healthcare 5.0. Numerous frameworks such as MeDShare [<a href="#B116-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">116</a>], Medblock [<a href="#B117-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">117</a>], HealthBlock [<a href="#B118-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">118</a>], and BLOSOM [<a href="#B119-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">119</a>] have been developed to secure patient records. BCIF-EHR, an interoperable blockchain-based framework proposed in [<a href="#B103-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">103</a>], facilitates seamless sharing and integration of electronic health records (EHRs) while preserving privacy and security. However, the framework requires a decentralised authentication and access control mechanism to restrict access to authorised entities only. Addressing this limitation, TrustHealth [<a href="#B104-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">104</a>] integrates blockchain with a trusted execution environment, designing a secure database that ensures the confidentiality and integrity of EHRs. TrustHealth also incorporates a secure session key generation protocol, enabling secure communication channels between healthcare providers and the trusted execution environment. Such advancements exemplify blockchain’s ability to transform healthcare by improving interoperability, security, and trust.</div><div class="html-p">Despite its broad applicability, blockchain faces challenges such as latency and high energy consumption, particularly in Proof-of-Work-based systems. These issues can hinder real-time applications and raise concerns about environmental sustainability. Additionally, blockchain’s reliance on distributed consensus mechanisms can lead to cold-start issues in networks with low node participation, delaying transaction validation. Overall, blockchain’s transformative potential lies in its ability to provide secure, transparent, and decentralised solutions across diverse sectors, fundamentally changing how data integrity and trust are managed.</div></section><section id="sec4dot2-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h4 class="html-italic" data-nested="2" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  4.2. Serverless Computing</h4><div class="html-p">The concept of serverless computing emerged in the mid-2000s with cloud services like Amazon S3 and EC2, which simplified infrastructure management for developers [<a href="#B120-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">120</a>]. However, a major breakthrough came in 2014 with the introduction of AWS Lambda [<a href="#B121-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">121</a>], which established the Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) model. This allowed developers to execute code in response to events without managing servers, providing automatic scaling and reducing operational overhead [<a href="#B122-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">122</a>]. IBM OpenWhisk (2016) later expanded on this concept by offering an open-source alternative that prioritised flexibility [<a href="#B123-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">123</a>]. Further advancements included Microsoft Azure Functions [<a href="#B124-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">124</a>] and Google Cloud Run [<a href="#B125-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">125</a>], which integrated containerised workloads to extend serverless capabilities.</div><div class="html-p">Serverless computing provides automatic scalability, eliminating the need for manual resource management. A key advantage of this model is its “pay-as-you-go” pricing structure, where users pay only for the compute time they consume rather than pre-allocated resources, significantly reducing costs for variable workloads [<a href="#B126-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">126</a>]. These benefits make serverless computing ideal for applications such as web services [<a href="#B127-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">127</a>], IoT [<a href="#B128-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">128</a>], and large-scale data processing [<a href="#B129-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">129</a>]. Industries including finance, healthcare, and e-commerce utilise serverless computing to enable rapid scaling and resource efficiency. Major companies like Netflix and Airbnb rely on serverless architectures to handle fluctuating traffic loads, ensuring a smooth user experience during peak demand [<a href="#B130-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">130</a>]. Studies indicate that serverless platforms can handle up to 10,000 concurrent function executions while maintaining response times below 500 ms, making them suitable for real-time applications [<a href="#B131-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">131</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Despite its advantages, serverless computing presents several challenges. One major concern is cold-start latency, which occurs when an idle function is invoked and requires initialisation. To mitigate this, techniques such as function pre-warming, optimising container configurations, and adjusting function granularity have been developed, reducing cold-start delays by up to 50% in production environments [<a href="#B132-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">132</a>,<a href="#B133-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">133</a>]. Another issue is vendor lock-in, where applications become dependent on proprietary cloud provider implementations. To overcome this, multi-cloud serverless frameworks like Knative and OpenFaaS have emerged, allowing developers to deploy serverless workloads across multiple providers, increasing flexibility and reducing dependency risks [<a href="#B134-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">134</a>]. Furthermore, serverless architectures are not well suited for long-running processes, as they impose execution time limits. Hybrid serverless–edge computing models are increasingly being explored to process latency-sensitive workloads closer to the data source, particularly for IoT applications [<a href="#B135-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">135</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Ongoing advancements aim to enhance serverless computing’s flexibility and performance. AI-based function pre-warming, such as Alibaba Cloud’s Function Compute prediction models, proactively warms up instances to reduce startup delays [<a href="#B136-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">136</a>]. Federated serverless architectures provide cost-effectiveness and resource efficiency [<a href="#B137-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">137</a>]. Additionally, confidential computing techniques like secure enclaves are being integrated to enhance function-level security, mitigating multi-tenant isolation concerns [<a href="#B138-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">138</a>]. For high-frequency workloads, the unpredictable costs of serverless computing can sometimes make traditional cloud computing a more economical option. Research into more transparent and cost-efficient serverless pricing structures is ongoing [<a href="#B139-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">139</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Overall, while serverless computing offers scalability, cost efficiency, and operational flexibility, its adoption requires addressing challenges related to latency, vendor dependence, and security. Continued advancements in optimisation techniques, multi-cloud interoperability, and pricing models will further enhance its impact on the future of cloud computing.</div></section><section id="sec4dot3-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h4 class="html-italic" data-nested="2" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  4.3. Cloud-Native Architectures</h4><div class="html-p">Cloud-native architectures began with distributed systems research in the 1990s [<a href="#B140-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">140</a>] and the introduction of virtualisation by VMware in 1998 [<a href="#B141-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">141</a>]. In 2006, AWS launched EC2 and S3, making on-demand cloud services widely available [<a href="#B120-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">120</a>]. DevOps ideas took off around 2009 [<a href="#B142-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">142</a>], combining development and operations to speed up software delivery. Docker emerged in 2013 as a platform for packaging applications into lightweight containers [<a href="#B143-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">143</a>], followed by Google’s open-source release of Kubernetes in 2014 to orchestrate and manage containerized workloads [<a href="#B144-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">144</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Docker emerged in 2013 for packaging applications into lightweight containers [<a href="#B143-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">143</a>], followed by Google’s open-source release of Kubernetes in 2014 to orchestrate and manage containerised workloads [<a href="#B144-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">144</a>]. The Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) formed in 2015 and made Kubernetes its first project [<a href="#B144-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">144</a>], while AWS Lambda (launched in 2014) introduced serverless computing [<a href="#B121-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">121</a>], and service meshes emerged to handle microservice communication [<a href="#B128-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">128</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Today, cloud-native architecture optimises cloud application performance by integrating microservices, containerisation, and continuous integration/continuous delivery (as shown in <a href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f007" class="html-fig html-figpopup">Figure 7</a>) [<a href="#B145-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">145</a>,<a href="#B146-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">146</a>]. These techniques enable modularity, scalability, and reliability. Microservices divide applications into independent, manageable services, containerisation ensures consistent deployment, and CI/CD accelerates the development life cycle, creating a robust framework for efficiently handling dynamic workloads. Tools like Docker and Kubernetes simplify container orchestration, streamline scaling, and accelerate deployment pipelines [<a href="#B147-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">147</a>]. Unlike traditional monolithic structures, cloud-native applications are modular, allowing components to be managed, scaled, and updated independently. This makes cloud-native architectures highly effective in dynamic environments demanding rapid iteration and resilient deployment [<a href="#B148-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">148</a>,<a href="#B149-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">149</a>,<a href="#B150-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">150</a>].</div><div class="html-fig-wrap" id="electronics-14-00677-f007">
  <div class="html-fig_img">
    <div class="html-figpopup html-figpopup-link" data-counterslinkmanual="https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9292/14/4/677/display" href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f007">

      <a class="html-expand html-figpopup" data-counterslinkmanual="https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9292/14/4/677/display" href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f007"></a>

  </div>

    <b>Figure 7.</b>
      Key building blocks of a cloud-native architecture. This figure illustrates the four fundamental components of cloud-native systems: containers, microservices, DevOps, and CI/CD. These elements enable scalability, automation, and continuous deployment in modern cloud computing environments.

      Click here to enlarge figure
    </a></p> -->

  </div>
</div><div class="html-p">Alongside these core components, advanced communication paradigms such as Partitioned Global Address Space (PGAS) models and Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) further enhance cloud-native platforms [<a href="#B151-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">151</a>]. PGAS models provide a shared memory abstraction across distributed systems, emphasising data locality and reducing communication overhead, making them particularly suitable for high-performance applications in cloud environments. RDMA further enhances infrastructure efficiency by enabling direct memory-to-memory transfers between nodes, bypassing CPU involvement to minimise latency and maximise throughput. These technologies are critical for optimising the performance of modern distributed systems and are increasingly adopted in cloud-native platforms.</div><div class="html-p">Cloud-native architectures also play a pivotal role in Industry 4.0, where real-time data processing across IoT and edge devices matters most. These architectures realise smooth integration in distributed systems, hence managing large-scale, latency-sensitive data efficiently [<a href="#B152-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">152</a>]. By incorporating PGAS and RDMA, these architectures can handle complex data flows and resource-intensive tasks with greater efficiency, supporting the scalability demands of Industry 4.0. One of the prominent design elements of cloud-native designs is the multi-cloud and distributed cloud models that, for instance, enable the deployment of applications across multiple cloud providers [<a href="#B153-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">153</a>]. This increases availability and avoids vendor lock-in, giving flexibility and resilience to enterprises by utilising unique services across cloud platforms [<a href="#B154-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">154</a>].</div><div class="html-p">On top of this, cloud-native architectures leverage Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) environments to simplify infrastructure management and scaling [<a href="#B155-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">155</a>]. Cloud federation strategies improve interoperability across providers, enabling seamless service migration and management in heterogeneous systems [<a href="#B156-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">156</a>]. Infrastructure as Code (IaC) automates resource provisioning, ensuring efficient and secure application deployment [<a href="#B157-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">157</a>]. By combining these methods with advanced communication paradigms, cloud-native architectures offer robust fault tolerance and high resource utilisation, supporting a range of workloads from e-commerce to scientific computing.</div><div class="html-p">Despite these benefits, cloud-native approaches come with their own set of challenges. Integrating PGAS and RDMA can be complex, requiring specialised hardware and in-depth expertise, which may raise costs and limit portability across diverse platforms. Deploying microservices at scale also necessitates comprehensive observability solutions to handle complex debugging and performance monitoring tasks. In multi-cloud scenarios, while the flexibility is appealing, organisations may still encounter partial vendor lock-in due to unique service integrations. Security remains a prominent concern, as misconfigurations in container orchestration or vulnerabilities within microservices can open pathways for data breaches. Additionally, the rapid pace of innovation in the cloud-native ecosystem demands continual learning and adaptation, placing pressure on both developers and operators to stay abreast of emerging tools and best practices [<a href="#B144-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">144</a>]. Balancing these challenges with the clear advantages of agility, scalability, and resilience is essential for successful adoption across various industries.</div></section><section id="sec4dot4-electronics-14-00677" type=""><h4 class="html-italic" data-nested="2" style="font-family: Arial, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">  4.4. Distributed AI and ML Systems</h4><div class="html-p">Distributed AI and ML systems are the backbone for scalable training and deployment of complex models across decentralised networks [<a href="#B158-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">158</a>]. Unlike the centralised approach, this architecture allows the computation to be distributed among different nodes, reducing the latency in training and efficiently processing large datasets [<a href="#B159-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">159</a>]. This ML approach can optimise learning and AI inference, particularly for resource-constrained devices such as IoT or edge computing devices used in real-time applications [<a href="#B160-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">160</a>]. It aligns with the principles of federated learning, which allow for collaborative model training without the need to share raw data, thus preserving data privacy and reducing bandwidth demands [<a href="#B161-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">161</a>]. By leveraging intelligent agents in a distributed environment, these systems can significantly reduce model training time while maintaining robust fault tolerance [<a href="#B162-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">162</a>]. Moreover, distributed learning algorithms applied in different application areas, such as 6G [<a href="#B163-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">163</a>] and smart grid systems [<a href="#B164-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">164</a>], illustrate how these methods can optimise resource usage and enable real-time decision-making with minimal latency. Advanced variants, such as AutoDAL, enable automatic hyperparameter tuning within distributed learning frameworks, addressing scalability and efficiency challenges in large-scale data analysis [<a href="#B165-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">165</a>].</div><div class="html-p">Federated learning is an emerging area in distributed AI, allowing model training across decentralised devices or servers without centralising raw data. This approach improves privacy and reduces data transfer costs, with models trained locally on edge devices and only shared parameters sent back to central servers, as shown in <a href="#fig_body_display_electronics-14-00677-f008" class="html-fig html-figpopup">Figure 8</a> [<a href="#B166-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">166</a>]. Federated learning is especially valuable in applications with strict privacy requirements, such as healthcare and finance, where regulatory constraints limit centralised data storage [<a href="#B167-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">167</a>]. However, federated systems face significant challenges in balancing privacy preservation and model accuracy. Privacy-preserving techniques, such as differential privacy and secure multi-party computation, introduce noise or encryption that can reduce model performance  [<a href="#B168-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">168</a>]. To address this, privacy-aware optimisation algorithms, such as those incorporating adaptive noise levels or secure aggregation protocols, have been proposed to maintain accuracy while ensuring data security [<a href="#B169-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">169</a>,<a href="#B170-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">170</a>]. Another critical challenge in federated systems is communication overhead, especially in scenarios involving frequent synchronisation of model updates across devices. This overhead can significantly increase latency and reduce efficiency in large-scale systems. Potential solutions include strategies like periodic aggregation, where updates are transmitted at predefined intervals rather than continuously [<a href="#B171-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">171</a>], and selective model updates, which prioritise transmitting critical updates based on gradient sparsity or importance [<a href="#B172-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">172</a>]. Additionally, techniques such as gradient compression and quantised updates can minimise communication costs without sacrificing accuracy, making federated learning more scalable and efficient in distributed environments [<a href="#B173-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">173</a>,<a href="#B174-electronics-14-00677" class="html-bibr" title="">174</a>]. These advancements demonstrate that federated learning can address privacy and efficiency challenges effectively, paving the way for its widespread adoption in privacy-sensitive domains.</div><div class="html-fig-wrap" id="electronics-14-00677-f008">
